awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Hurricane Ian's overwash deposit: impacts of high-intensity landfalling tropical cyclones in southwest Florida
awd_abstract_narration:
Tropical cyclones are amongst the most dangerous and costly natural hazards to impact U.S. coastlines. These events will have worsening effects with changing storm characteristics and sea-level rise in a warming climate. Most recently, southwest Florida has been impacted by two Category 4 hurricanes, Irma in 2017 and Ian in 2022. Two major events in the same region within 5 years presents a unique opportunity to study geological data from these storms. This rapid response project will explore the impact of high-intensity hurricanes by collecting geological data related to Hurricane Ian’s storm surge and sedimentary deposit. Further, previous work on Hurricane Irma in 2017 and 2019 will allow for a comparison between these two recent events. This multiple storm focus will help to understand the impact of hurricanes across the southwest Florida coast. The data will also add further knowledge about the preservation of geological deposits from repeated storms. Such data are crucial to improve understanding of past and present storm activity. The project advances broader representation in STEM through support of an all-female team of early career scientists and as well as undergraduate and graduate students.

To extend our understanding of past tropical cyclones, we rely on geologic records to reconstruct a history of cyclone intensity and frequency beyond the instrumental period. However, reconstructing geologic records of tropical cyclones relies on modern analog studies of overwash deposits and how they are preserved in coastal environments. The aim of this study is to investigate two sites in southwest Florida by 1) measuring land elevation and recording the thickness and landward extent of Hurricane Ian’s overwash deposit and 2) comparing Ian’s deposit with a previous hurricane (Hurricane Irma) which also made landfall and deposited sediments throughout southwest Florida in 2017. The project is enabled by previous field investigations in 2017 and 2019 which documented Hurricane Irma overwash sediments in southwest Florida. Samples will be collected for sedimentologic (grain-size and organic content), geochemical (stable carbon isotopes and C/N values), and microfossil (foraminifera) analyses to compare biogeochemical indicators from Ian, Irma, and pre-storm sediments. Results of this project will advance paleo-storm studies in the sub-tropical southern Florida region by identifying key biogeochemical indicators and providing critical insight into the preservation potential of hurricane deposits in areas impacted by repeated, high-intensity hurricanes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tropical cyclones have dangerous and costly impacts on U.S. coastlines and will have worsening effects in a warming climate as sea-level continues to rise and storm characteristics are altered. We explored the impact of high-intensity tropical cyclones after the landfall of Hurricane Ian (Category 4 intensity) in September 2022 in southwest Florida by examining and collecting samples of the overwash deposit left behind from the hurricane in the coastal mangrove environment. Studying in this region also allowed us to compare two recent events, as southwest Florida was also impacted by Hurricane Irma (Category 3 intensity) five years earlier, in September 2017. Understanding how overwash deposits from tropical cyclones are incorporated into the mangrove sediment record provide key insights into how to identify evidence for previous tropical cyclones within the geologic record. Being able to identify these tropical cyclones in the geologic record allows us to extend our understanding of tropical cyclone frequency for the region. Through analyses of the tropical cyclone overwash deposit, as well as the underlying mangrove peat sediment, we found that geochemical and physical sediment characteristics can effectively differentiate the storm overwash from the mangrove sediment. Further, the now buried overwash sediment from Hurricane Irma from 2017 is also still distinguishable from surrounding mangrove sediment through the same geochemical and physical sediment characteristics. Our results suggest that tropical cyclone overwash sediments are well-preserved in mangrove environments (even when high-intensity events occur within 5 years) in the southwestern Florida region.

For this project, we were able to collect data from the tropical cyclone overwash sediment, which is perishable as samples can be lost due to clean-up efforts or natural processes such as erosion. This data is vital to understanding the impact of Hurricane Ian’s flooding along the southwest Florida coast and gave us the opportunity to compare Hurricane Ian’s overwash signature with Hurricane Irma’s overwash sediments. Results from this work will be highly beneficial to a wide variety of stakeholders and coastal decisionmakers as our coastal communities work to create more resilient coastlines in the face of a changing climate. Further, this project provided research opportunities to early-career scientists and students in the Geosciences. Our team was composed of female scientists who are predominantly early-career researchers. The work also supported undergraduate and graduate students, several of whom were from underrepresented groups, through participation in field and laboratory work, presentation of scientific results, and writing of peer-reviewed manuscripts.


Last Modified: 04/27/2024
Modified by: Jennifer S Walker
